misconceptions.name: Reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers for the required problem
misconceptions.description: The program is written for an average acceleration calculation and only reads three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers for summing even numbers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles to compute average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read exactly 5 integer values from the user (e.g., using nextInt() in a loop or sequentially), because the task is to sum the even numbers among those 5 integers.
symptoms: Prompt message asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Uses nextDouble() three times instead of nextInt() five times
No handling of five separate integer inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a completely different textbook example (average acceleration) instead of the specified problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the input section to ask for and read 5 integers, using nextInt() for each value (ideally inside a loop that runs 5 times). Ignore v0, v1, and t for this task.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt and variable names clearly correspond to an acceleration example, with exactly three doubles read instead of five integers.

evidence.note: Reads three doubles labeled v0, v1, and t instead of five integers as required by the problem.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The program does not use any loop to process multiple user inputs; it reads a fixed number of values directly and performs a single calculation.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can read each needed value once and compute the result directly without looping.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To handle 5 integers in a scalable way, the program should use a loop (e.g., for or while) that iterates 5 times, reading one integer per iteration and updating the sum.
symptoms: No for or while loop present
Inputs are read via separate statements rather than inside a loop
Logic cannot easily scale or clearly reflect '5 integers' requirement
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a single-formula computation rather than iterative processing of a fixed count of inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop that runs 5 times, reading each integer within the loop body and checking/updating the sum there.
related_concepts: Iterating over a fixed number of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no loop construct at all, and all inputs are read with individual statements.

evidence.note: Reads inputs and computes the result directly with no loop.

misconceptions.name: Missing conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The code never checks whether a number is even (e.g., using n % 2 == 0), so it cannot filter or sum only even integers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I only need to compute (v1 - v0) / t without considering even/odd numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For each of the 5 integers read, the program should check if the number is even using a modulus condition (n % 2 == 0) and only add it to the sum if it is even.
symptoms: No use of the modulus operator (%) in the program
No if-statement or conditional logic related to even/odd checking
Output is based solely on an arithmetic formula unrelated to even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student solved a different physics formula problem and never addressed the even-number filtering requirement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer, add an if (n % 2 == 0) check before adding n to the sum variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no conditional related to parity or any use of %; the logic is purely arithmetic on three doubles.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The average acceleration is %s", (v1 - v0) / t);
evidence.note: Final computation uses only (v1 - v0) / t, with no conditional logic for even numbers.

misconceptions.name: No accumulator for sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program does not maintain an accumulator variable to store the running sum of even numbers; instead it directly computes a single expression (v1 - v0) / t and prints it.
misconceptions.student_belief: I only need to compute and print a single formula result without maintaining a sum over multiple inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should maintain an integer sum variable initialized to 0, add each even integer to it inside a loop, and then print the final sum with the specified message.
symptoms: No variable representing a running sum
No repeated addition operations over the inputs
Output label and value correspond to average acceleration, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student reused an example focused on a direct formula calculation instead of an accumulation pattern over multiple values.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an int sum = 0 before the loop; whenever an input is even, do sum += n; after the loop, print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no accumulator variable or repeated addition; only one arithmetic expression is computed and printed.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The average acceleration is %s", (v1 - v0) / t);
evidence.note: Prints a single formula result with no accumulation of a sum.
